wordpressPost.title: Why one of the "Best Lawyers in America" says corporate green initiatives work: An interview with Suz Mac Cormac
wordpressPost.content:
Recent research indicates that 69% of large organizations have corporate green initiatives in place (Source: Buck Consultants). But how effective is it, really, to engage your employees in environmental sustainability?
A few weeks ago, I sat down with Suz Mac Cormac, a partner in the Corporate Department at Morrison Foerster’s (self proclaimed, MoFo) San Francisco office, to discuss the internal sustainability committee she started in 2005. Suz had offhandedly mentioned the committee to me about a month ago and I wanted to know more. Here’s a great story about the positive impact employee engagement programs can have on changing a company.

The C-Suite Support

In 2004, Suz was a Tier 8 Partner’lowest on the partner totem pole’but she was young, and had a track record of generating money for the firm. She went around to every Tier 1 partner that she knew, and made the business case for sustainability. I had a lot of charts, and figures, and graphs, she said. She was eventually given a speaking role at the partner retreat later that year.
Suz knew her audience, and did not want to come across as a tree-hugging Californian speaking to a fairly conservative firm. I was all about the numbers, and about the amount of investment that needed to be made, and infrastructure, and energy. The business case was clear, but she kept throwing in, if we are going to focus on this externally, we need to focus on this internally.

Up & Running

There was much interest after the partner retreat so she set up an internal sustainability committee made up of attorneys and staff from each of the offices. This was formally launched in 2005. Anyone who wanted to be involved on the committee could be’even the guy in the mailroom.
There were certain people, who took it and ran with it’you didn’t know where it would come from, said Suz.
For example, the reason they have a web site to drive employee engagement in sustainability is because Tony Hoke, a Sr. Global Sourcing Manager at MoFo, and a couple others in the IT department took it upon on themselves to build it.

Execution

Co-chaired by Associate, Adam Hunt, and firm-wide Manager of Operations, Peter Elton, the Internal Sustainability Committee (ISC) has calls regularly with a predetermined agenda. They discuss operational inefficiencies, even engaging outside consultants when necessary. Early on, they hired BSR to do an internal audit, and had them list potential corporate green initiatives as either cost-savings, cost-neutral, or costly. With this information, they were able to make improvements to the point where the SF office became LEED Gold certified. In addition to office improvements, the ISC sets actionable company goals for sustainability issues, such as reducing paper usage. They then communicate and track the initiatives through their employee engagement portal page, Eco-Challenge.
Eco-Challenge encourages participation with gamification, by awarding points to employees who engage in positive actions like bike-to-work week, the EPA’s WasteWise program, or simply turning the monitor off when not in use. Employees then put those points towards rewards like an eco-bag, or extra votes to decide what non-profit the firm will donate to. Furthermore, Eco-Challenge tracks engagement by office, which has led to friendly competition between offices all over the world and allows the team to measure the success of the program.

The Results

This year, Vault.com ranked MoFo as the #1 law firm in CleanTech/Renewable Energy and Technology. According to Suz, the reason they can do this work is because there is a business for it. The reason they have been so successful is a result of the sustainability committee getting people excited and knowledgeable about the corporate green initiatives. RFP wise, MoFo is able to provide legal service to clients with even the most robust questions on internal environmental sustainability’ JP Morgan is one of these.
Suz went on to point out that driving employee engagement in sustainability has had been beneficial for the firm on the employee acquisition and retention front, recognizing the platform as a driver for more of the best and brightest to want to come work for the law firm. When I asked her how she knows this, she said, Because they come and ask about it.
Sustainability is such a hit at MoFo that posted on the front page of the main company portal is a big green leaf with the green tip of the day.
“Have you turned off your monitor today?”

Susan Mac Cormac is a partner in the Corporate Department of Morrison & Foerster’s San Francisco office. She serves as co-chair of the Clean Technology and Renewable Energy Group and the Private Equity and Venture Investment Practice. Ms. Mac Cormac has extensive experience representing startup to late-stage private companies primarily in the clean technology, renewable energy and sustainable space. She provides corporate and finance advice in connection with equity and debt financings, mergers, acquisitions, asset purchases and sales, reorganizations, and joint ventures. She regularly advises boards of private and public companies, special committees, and CEOs on corporate governance as it relates to sustainability and Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) issues and has joined the faculty (teaching on issues of sustainability and corporate governance) at both the Stanford Director’s College and the Northwestern Corporate Counsel Institute. In addition to her representation of nonprofit corporations involved with Sustainability and CSR, providing advice to their boards on fiduciary issues, conflicts of interest, and other corporate matters, she has deep experience and expertise in structure for nonprofit/for-profit Hybrids and new corporate forms. Ms. Mac Cormac was selected by her peers for Best Lawyers in America 2011-2014.
